fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Student at GÃ¶teborgs universitet.
This website is created using Jon Sterling's Forester tool. I maintain a collection of my personal notes here.
A monoidal category consists of the following data.

fr:ul.fr:li: A functor { \otimes }:{ \mathsf { C } \times \mathsf { C } } \xrightarrow {{}}{ \mathsf { C } } called the monoidal product.
An object \mathbb {1} \in \mathsf { C } called the monoidal unit.
A natural isomorphism { \alpha _{ X , Y , Z } }:{ (X \otimes Y) \otimes Z } \xrightarrow {{}}{ X \otimes (Y \otimes Z) } called the associator.
A natural isomorphism { \lambda _{ X } }:{ \mathbb {1} \otimes X } \xrightarrow {{}}{ X } called the left unitor.
A natural isomorphism { \rho _{ X } }:{ X \otimes \mathbb {1} } \xrightarrow {{}}{ X } called the right unitor.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the following axioms.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = (X \otimes \mathbb {1} ) \otimes Y, sw = X \otimes Y, se = X \otimes Y, ne = X \otimes ( \mathbb {1} \otimes Y), east = X \otimes \lambda _{ Y } , west = \rho _{ X } \otimes Y, north = \alpha _{ X , \mathbb {1} , Y } , south/style = {equal}, height = 1.5cm, width = 3.5cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Moreover the equality { \lambda _{ \mathbb {1} } = \rho _{ \mathbb {1} } }:{ \mathbb {1} \otimes \mathbb {1} } \xrightarrow {{}}{ \mathbb {1} } holds.
The following diagram commutes.
The following diagram commutes.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = (X \otimes \mathbb {1} ) \otimes Y, sw = X \otimes Y, se = X \otimes Y, ne = X \otimes ( \mathbb {1} \otimes Y), east = X \otimes \lambda _{ Y } , west = \rho _{ X } \otimes Y, north = \alpha _{ X , \mathbb {1} , Y } , south/style = {equal}, height = 1.5cm, width = 3.5cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Moreover the equality { \lambda _{ \mathbb {1} } = \rho _{ \mathbb {1} } }:{ \mathbb {1} \otimes \mathbb {1} } \xrightarrow {{}}{ \mathbb {1} } holds.

I am a dinosaur so I still prefer to hand write my notes and then tex them up in Emacs. As the number of notes increases over the years, I often find myself re-texing the same things over and over again because it is often faster than finding and referencing the corresponding notes, most of which are not even in the same tex file.
Forester allows me to link notes more easily. It also generates contexts, backlinks, and related links automatically. I think these features are what I am looking for, so I am trying out this tool.
I have managed to produce the following (incomplete) definition in Forester. I have to spend some time digging through Jon Sterling's public trees to figure out how to draw diagrams in this language.
A monoidal category consists of the following data.

fr:ul.fr:li: A functor { \otimes }:{ \mathsf { C } \times \mathsf { C } } \xrightarrow {{}}{ \mathsf { C } } called the monoidal product.
An object \mathbb {1} \in \mathsf { C } called the monoidal unit.
A natural isomorphism { \alpha _{ X , Y , Z } }:{ (X \otimes Y) \otimes Z } \xrightarrow {{}}{ X \otimes (Y \otimes Z) } called the associator.
A natural isomorphism { \lambda _{ X } }:{ \mathbb {1} \otimes X } \xrightarrow {{}}{ X } called the left unitor.
A natural isomorphism { \rho _{ X } }:{ X \otimes \mathbb {1} } \xrightarrow {{}}{ X } called the right unitor.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the following axioms.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = (X \otimes \mathbb {1} ) \otimes Y, sw = X \otimes Y, se = X \otimes Y, ne = X \otimes ( \mathbb {1} \otimes Y), east = X \otimes \lambda _{ Y } , west = \rho _{ X } \otimes Y, north = \alpha _{ X , \mathbb {1} , Y } , south/style = {equal}, height = 1.5cm, width = 3.5cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Moreover the equality { \lambda _{ \mathbb {1} } = \rho _{ \mathbb {1} } }:{ \mathbb {1} \otimes \mathbb {1} } \xrightarrow {{}}{ \mathbb {1} } holds.
The following diagram commutes.

I am joining GÃ¶teborgs universitet in the autumn of 2024. Before that, I was a student at the University at Buffalo, where I earned my Master's degree in computer science. I am mainly interested in category theory and topos theory and their application in logic.
fr:mainmatter.fr:blockquote: ,,Entweder ist die Mathematik zu groÃ fÃ¼r den menschlichen Verstand oder der menschlichen Verstand ist mehr als eine Maschine''. - Kurt GÃ¶del

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This website is created using Jon Sterling's Forester tool. I maintain a collection of my personal notes here.

I am a dinosaur so I still prefer to hand write my notes and then tex them up in Emacs. As the number of notes increases over the years, I often find myself re-texing the same things over and over again because it is often faster than finding and referencing the corresponding notes, most of which are not even in the same tex file.
Forester allows me to link notes more easily. It also generates contexts, backlinks, and related links automatically. I think these features are what I am looking for, so I am trying out this tool.
I have managed to produce the following (incomplete) definition in Forester. I have to spend some time digging through Jon Sterling's public trees to figure out how to draw diagrams in this language.
A monoidal category consists of the following data.

fr:ul.fr:li: A functor { \otimes }:{ \mathsf { C } \times \mathsf { C } } \xrightarrow {{}}{ \mathsf { C } } called the monoidal product.
An object \mathbb {1} \in \mathsf { C } called the monoidal unit.
A natural isomorphism { \alpha _{ X , Y , Z } }:{ (X \otimes Y) \otimes Z } \xrightarrow {{}}{ X \otimes (Y \otimes Z) } called the associator.
A natural isomorphism { \lambda _{ X } }:{ \mathbb {1} \otimes X } \xrightarrow {{}}{ X } called the left unitor.
A natural isomorphism { \rho _{ X } }:{ X \otimes \mathbb {1} } \xrightarrow {{}}{ X } called the right unitor.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the following axioms.
The following diagram commutes.
